commit_message:
Display the error message on create volume group form

On create volume group form, if the volume type is not selected,
the creation is not successful, but no prompt message is shown.
This patch display error message when volume type is not selected

Change-Id: Ib7d7531a3cdeb6166dd63381901bc4ba2db412e0
Closes-Bug: #1825952

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-20 20:22:31.000000000', 'message': "WIP - Don't throw valueerror on bootstrap

When keystone-manage bootstrap is ran without providing a value
to set as the admin password, keystone-manage will throw an
unhandled ValueError while displaying the proper warning
message.

This change removes the ValueError and simply has the CLI
exit out when this condition is met.

Closes-Bug: #1804700

Change-Id: I4e7d5eeb2e48ff354b44196bd11d62d51a73357b

to set as the admin password, keystone-manage will throw an

commit_message:
Don't throw valueerror on bootstrap

When keystone-manage bootstrap is ran without providing a value
to set as the admin password, keystone-manage will throw an
unhandled ValueError while displaying the proper warning
message.

This change removes the ValueError and simply has the CLI
exit out when this condition is met.

Closes-Bug: #1804700

Change-Id: I4e7d5eeb2e48ff354b44196bd11d62d51a73357b

commit_message:
Add support for network-data-file.

TripleO offers a default network topology when deploying
with network isolation enabled, and this is reflected in
the network_data.yaml file in tripleo-heat-templates.
If this is the case it has to be handled during update/upgrade.

Change-Id: If50109753d4845357c869986c256186e8e22006d

commit_message:
Use make_url to wrap IPv6 addresses in brackets.

Replace the dependency of network data values for wrapping
'ip_address_uri' in brackets. Instead of using jinja2
variables network.ipv6 or ipv6_override to decide if the
IP need to be wrapped in brackets or not the make_url
function in heat in combination with a str_replace is
used.

Related-Bug: #1830406
Change-Id: I2d8c405c1df30ac11cc2286398fe4749694da10e

commit_message:
Add CephAnsibleEnvironmentVariables to nodes-uuid call

CephAnsibleEnvironmentVariables are also useful when running
the nodes-uuid playbook. Users may know ceph-ansible playbook
is run but may not know the nodes-uuid playbook is run too.
If additional Ansible environment variables are useful for
running ceph-ansible it is likely they will be needed for
the nodes-uuid playbook. The altnernative is to create another
parameter like NodesUuidAnsibleEnvironmentVariables.

Change-Id: I10ddb4f79f5c8b69b09622b96e96325ba19d62e0
(cherry picked from commit 6858ef41146d5afdbfe614e6f3d8f9727a5b2563)

commit_message:
[Python3] Adds bytes to str conversion management

On RHEL8 with Python3, the template's contents returned by the Swift
client get_object method is byte object and need to be converted into a
string.

Change-Id: Ia35abb66b9e61a7154406cf83c6da1e68a2f96b7
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit f144be5bcc0e6bbe4f5541f60bab4b513855c826)

commit_message:
Do not check name duplication when creating a volume group

The cinder service allows to use a same name for multiple groups.
There is no need to check whether the name already is used in
the "Create Volume Group" form.

Change-Id: If6f33f1a23ffaddbada614306f9cf9844e8be1e4
Closes-Bug: #1825954

commit_message:
Stop all services before upgrading node's OS.

During the system_upgrade_prepare step in the upgrade
workflow, we need to stop all services before starting
the operating system upgrade, we're doing that by stopping
all docker containers at once after stopping the pcmkr
cluster in step 2.

Change-Id: I50a1289a864f804d02a2e2bc0ca8738a186beff0

commit_message:
Configure server_certs_key_passphrase for Octavia

A recent change[1] to Octavia added a parameter named
server_certs_key_passphrase, which means that TripleO should
generate a password for it to avoid using the default value.

This patch adds OctaviaServerCertsKeyPassphrase to the list
of parameters TripleO configures in Octavia.

Closes-Bug: #1821756
Related-Bug: #1821751

[1] I06d329ca53bc36bd27f7870ae7c7ca0cf18575b2
Depends-On: I9699961faf8b3430e4372e4ff3ae2bf7e7ceea18
Depends-On: Id6c0d156715147c6559dc39098a6eaabf77ac426
Depends-On: I5e60e8fbb7af381b59c6d7b02d5ba8eb47e91720
Change-Id: Icadd090f027af6f958c25af6bfb09195a4019aa8

commit_message:
Blacklist bandit and update sphinx requirement

The change blacklists the buggy version of bandit (1.6.0) and syncs
sphinx dependency with global requirements. It caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.

Change-Id: I21c8a7ef793874a5ab7a4d277c9c3eb13896503d
Story: 2005676
Task: 30990

commit_message:
Configure server_certs_key_passphrase for Octavia

A recent change[1] to Octavia added a parameter named
server_certs_key_passphrase, which means that TripleO should
generate a password for it to avoid using the default value.

Closes-Bug: #1821751

[1] I06d329ca53bc36bd27f7870ae7c7ca0cf18575b2

commit_message:
Add passphrase generation for Octavia

A recent change[1] to Octavia added a parameter named
server_certs_key_passphrase, which means that we should generate a
password for it to avoid using the default value.

This patch adds OctaviaServerCertsKeyPassphrase to the list of
generated password/secrets, similarly to this past change[2].

Closes-Bug: #1821756
Related-Bug: #1821751

[1] I06d329ca53bc36bd27f7870ae7c7ca0cf18575b2
[2] I1dd1873b646e8569ed0a85c5ee7eb3bec3a8b1fa

Change-Id: I9699961faf8b3430e4372e4ff3ae2bf7e7ceea18

commit_message:
Populate pools upon namespace creation

When namespace subnet driver is used, a new subnet is created for
each new namespace. As pools are created per subnet, this patch
ensures that new ports are created for each pool for the new subnet
in the nested case.

Note this feature depends on using resource tagging to filter out
trunk ports in case of multiple clusters deployed on the same openstack
project or when other trunks are present. Otherwise it will consider
all the existing trunks no matter if they belong or not to the
kubernetes cluster.

NOTE: this is only for nested case, where pooling shows the greatest
improvements as ports are already ACTIVE.

Change-Id: Id014cf49da8d4cbe0c1795e47765fcf2f0684c09

commit_message:
Remove tempest.test_plugins from setup.cfg

This commit removes tempest.test_plugins entry from setup.cfg since we
already removed it in the past commit[0]. Otherwise, the
plugin-sanity-check job in tempest would be failed and the
plugin-registry page[1] would be incorrect.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/656707/
[1] https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/plugin-registry.html

Change-Id: If529503286eb23ffa80880ae94cca143ae798729

commit_message:
Change repository links usage in Dockerfile and build image

Used to be: git.openstack.org/openstack/monasca-persister?h=stable/pike
Now : opendev.org/openstack/monasca-persister/src/branch/stable/pike

Since the way links to specific branches changed, usage of
those links has to be changed as well.
CONSTRAINTS_BRANCH variable was removed because CONSTRAINTS_FILE
contains link to the upper-requirements file with specified branch.

Story: 2005666
Task: 30970
Change-Id: I704cd025d6ccf7e9769a276d6094c4e2f3fb69ef

for non-TC-governed OpenStack projects are not synced automatically.
group-based-policy-ui is such repository.
It is a good chance to point repositories on opendev.org.
This commit replaces github links to opendev links.

commit_message:
Update URLs of horizon plugin registry

As result of the recent opendev migration, github repositories
for non-TC-governed OpenStack projects are not synced automatically.
group-based-policy-ui is such repository.
It is a good chance to point repositories on opendev.org.
This commit replaces github links to opendev links.

This commit also updates bug tracker links to more direct links
to the bug trackers.

sphinx extlink is now used to simplify the plugin registry doc.

Change-Id: Ib1a746e2cd6c7ed0c81c10e2767d6f76ad0203b9

[{'created': '2019-04-01 16:00:12.000000000', 'message': 'Fix tempest volume tests on queens

With [1], keystone catalog entries are no longer created for cinder's
v1 API. This works fine with the latest version of tempest, but older
versions of tempest assume a service named "volume" is present in the
catalog. This patch ensures the service exists, but reuses the endpoints
from cinder's v3 API.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/644550

Closes-Bug: #1822080
Change-Id: If1ef8b1ad60151c0dfd0a7804ba7e697fc4ede28

With [1], keystone catalog entries are no longer created for cinder's
v1 API. This works fine with the latest version of tempest, but older
versions of tempest assume a service named "volume" is present in the

commit_message:
Fix tempest volume tests on queens

With [1], keystone catalog entries are no longer created for cinder's
v1 API. This works fine with the latest version of tempest, but older
versions of tempest assume a service named "volume" is present in the
catalog. This patch ensures the service exists, but reuses the endpoints
from cinder's v3 API.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/644550

Closes-Bug: #1822080
Change-Id: If1ef8b1ad60151c0dfd0a7804ba7e697fc4ede28

messages:
[{'account_id': 25805, 'date': '2018-01-14 12:42:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-07-16 20:53:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

This matches my understanding of the recommended ceph.conf handling.'}, {'account_id': 27882, 'date': '2018-08-28 09:37:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 27882, 'date': '2018-08-28 09:38:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Corrected commit message (added permalink) and rebased on current master.'}, {'account_id': 27882, 'date': '2018-08-28 09:40:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-08-28 12:00:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

This does match what was done in Cinder and from talking to the RBD maintainers this is the preferred way.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-10-23 14:24:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I agree with Sean that this is the correct way to handle this.  The -1 is because I'd like you to update the help text to reflect your change.  (The config file help text serves as the documentation for most of the drivers.)"}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-10-23 14:25:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Oh yeah, and sorry that this has sat for 2 months.  I'll promise to keep an eye on it & review as soon as you make the change."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-02-15 15:00:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review

Any updates on this? The stein library freeze is coming up soon, so if we want to get this in we need to get it sorted out relatively quickly.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-02-22 15:21:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

Dropping my -1.  The code looks fine; no need to hold this up.

I submitted the help text change I requested as a follow-up patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/638686/'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2019-02-22 17:45:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I need to have a look if I can find the old bug report/patch proposed for this. We've discussed this before.

My problem with this is that we're handing over our config file management to 3rd party that can transparently change it and the deployments won't work without specific operator action. Which obviously is really bad idea (and before you even start librados has done it before, around the time this was proposed first). The fact that it happens to work with current version does not mean it wont bite us back in the future.

If we decide to do this change, we definitely need to change the wording in our docs to point out that the "configs needs to be where ever the used version of librados happens to look for them" instead of specifying the path.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-02-25 16:36:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Erno: I understand your concern, but I think this is a good change because: (1) it's consistent with Cinder, and (2) if an operator actually does want to rely on the default Ceph config file location in their current deployment, this patch gives them a way to do that.  Your point that which file is being used could change if librados is upgraded independently of glance_store is well-taken; I updated the follow-up patch to point that out."}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2019-05-29 08:53:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I can live with this together with the doc change.'}]

commit_message:
Conditional hidden arg for backward compatibility

At the moment, the python-magnumclient supplies the "hidden" arg when
creating cluster/cluster templates which is not backward compatible with
pre-Stein Magnum. This patch addresses the issue.

Story: 2005539
Task: 30678

Change-Id: Ib2c17cc0c244a89c700f309dc7dd971596fb0957

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I0e2e84a17952bbd03b670144b906d61680bc1360

subject: Enable keepalived VRRP health check
messages:
[{'account_id': 2711, 'date': '2019-05-22 06:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20634, 'date': '2019-05-24 09:05:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 20634, 'date': '2019-05-24 09:06:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

As this seems to be new feature work, I'm nervous about moving forward on a backport with this change"}, {'account_id': 20147, 'date': '2019-05-24 11:12:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2019-05-28 14:40:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm largely in agreement with icey -- this does seem like new feature work, and not a bug fix.  Please could a rationale be provided for why this should be back-ported (i.e it's causing another service to error, etc.).  Thank you."}, {'account_id': 2711, 'date': '2019-05-29 09:57:13.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Hi Alex and icey, I'm going to abandon this change, thanks for the review"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-22 06:34:54.000000000', 'message': "Enable keepalived VRRP health check

If you want to have vrrp watch the external networking interface
today, the option ha_vrrp_health_check_interval [1] detects a failure
it re-triggers the transitional change - which works if the external
physical interface fails because the ping will fail.

In fact, we've tried to enable it before [2], but then we had to
revert it [3] due to instability issues [4] in previous releases of
OpenStack. Maybe the previous instability issue [4] was caused by
another keepalived issue mentioned in the comment [5], now I have
tested this option again, it works.

This is how neutron allows monitoring southbound network today, so
I would suggest we add this capability into the charm again.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/ocata/networking-guide/ \
        deploy-ovs-ha-vrrp.html#keepalived-vrrp-health-check
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/601533/

commit_message:
Enable keepalived VRRP health check

If you want to have vrrp watch the external networking interface
today, the option ha_vrrp_health_check_interval [1] detects a failure
it re-triggers the transitional change - which works if the external
physical interface fails because the ping will fail.

In fact, we've tried to enable it before [2], but then we had to
revert it [3] due to instability issues [4] in previous releases of
OpenStack. Maybe the previous instability issue [4] was caused by
another keepalived issue mentioned in the comment [5], now I have
tested this option again, it works.

This is how neutron allows monitoring southbound network today, so
I would suggest we add this capability into the charm again.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/ocata/networking-guide/ \
        deploy-ovs-ha-vrrp.html#keepalived-vrrp-health-check
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/601533/
[3] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/603347/
[4] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1793102
[5] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1793102/comments/5

Change-Id: If2947e7640545cb9a48215afb9b2439fdc33c645
Closes-Bug: 1825966
(cherry picked from commit 4c150529b5725e25bfe53d7db15f2f11410c6111)
Signed-off-by: Zhang Hua <joshua.zhang@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Change repository links usage in Dockerfile and build image

Used to be: git.openstack.org/openstack/monasca-persister?h=stable/pike
Now : opendev.org/openstack/monasca-persister/src/branch/stable/pike

Since the way links to specific branches changed, usage of
those links has to be changed as well.
CONSTRAINTS_BRANCH variable was removed because CONSTRAINTS_FILE
contains link to the upper-requirements file with specified branch.

Story: 2005666
Task: 30968
Change-Id: I57c09bb50138bf829f39d4034bbc78356e34f3a6

commit_message:
Add py36 to default tox environments

Seems like I46b077f268d3a812e36f3de532ce1bfe7636166c removed py35 from
the default tox environments. This commit adds py36 there instead to
make sure Python 3 is covered.

Also debug-py35 env is updated to debug-py36 to remove py35 completely,
which is what aforementioned commit was intending to do.

Change-Id: I5a6fdaa0b5d94b9d2827a1a3889a00fce121cf6d

subject: Allow disabling load balancing
messages:
[{'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2019-05-08 12:31:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2019-05-08 14:08:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I'm guessing this will need an associated charm-helpers-sync to bring in the functionality being added in charm-helpers?"}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2019-05-10 09:26:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Alex,

I'm not sure. I think this one should be merged first and https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/319 later, as it depends on the relation data set by this patch."}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2019-05-10 11:43:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Tytus
This patch depends on the c-h PR ... i.e. the disable loadbalancing. THIS patch therefore will need that code from c-h to get the functionality from the config.yaml parameter change this patchset introduces.  i.e. it needs a charm-helpers sync to pull that code in.

Otherwise, as it stands, this change will have no effect on the charm, until some future charm-helpers sync (usually due to the release process or some other, unrelated, c-h change needed in the charm).'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2019-05-13 08:51:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Alex,

I don't wanna argue here, but please think it over. In the ultimate feature the hacluster charm won't execute the corresponding charm-helpers code. Those will be OpenStack charms who will do that. For example:

https://github.com/openstack/charm-swift-proxy/blob/master/lib/swift_utils.py#L153

Therefore, from my point of view, the revision sequence should be as follows:

1) Review and merge the patch for the hacluster charm
2) Review and merge the patch for charm-helpers
3) Sync the patch for charm-helpers with the OpenStack charms

Otherwise, the corresponding patch for charm-helpers (without the patch for the hacluster charm) may cause issues when using dev branches, as it will fail to obtain the relation data from the ha relation:

https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/319/files#diff-bceb54a0fa3aac4f53f131205411c18fR721

Anyway, I am not an expert here, so please treat it as a comment. I am fully happy to follow your path :)."}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2019-05-21 11:51:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think I've misunderstood how this code change works, and I think that's because I'm surprised about *how* it does work.  AFAICT, all this change does is introduce a config change into hacluster and then set it on the relation?

Then, a 'target' change will use this to write to a config file in the target charm, that writes the haproxy.conf file.

So the question is: why isn't the config value IN the target charm's config.yaml as that's where the change is used?"}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2019-05-22 08:11:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Alex,

Thank you for your input. This is a good question. I was thinking about that before I started the actual work on this patch and my question was different: why is the hacluster charm designed so that it does not manage HAProxy configuration file? My understanding was that the hacluster charm manages all HA-related services: corosync, pacemaker and haproxy.

We could move this option to the swift-proxy charm - sure. However, this solution doesn't scale. Leaving it in the hacluster charm would allow other OpenStack services to just consume it. On the other hand, there are other HA-related options (e.g. vip) which are set in the OpenStack charms rather than in the hacluster charm, so I am not sure.

What do you think? I am open for any suggestions."}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2019-05-22 13:22:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

Hi Tytus

Yes, it does seem odd that the hacluster charm doesn't manage the haproxy config file.  However, I *think* that is a historical artefact where the principal charms managed haproxy before the hacluster charm was born.

Having had a look at the config.yaml for swift-proxy (as an example), I still believe that this config option should be on the swift-proxy charm (and others).  All of the other haproxy config options appear within the swift-proxy charm (as an example) ... e.g. ha-bindiface, ha-mcastport, etc.  Therefore, I suspect that if this config item was called "ha-lb-enable" then it would fit right in.

My recommendation is to abandon this change, and make it config option on each relevant charm, and not propagate it via the relation.

However, I'm not the 'last authority' on this, so please seek another opinion if my recommendation doesn't sit well with you (i.e. I may be completely wrong).  I'm going to drop my -1 and put it back to 0.  If you like, I can mention it to other core reviewers?'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-05-25 20:55:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Not sure if this patch will be abandoned or not, but would like to highlight the typo in the commit message'}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2019-05-29 08:51:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Alex,

I think you managed to convince me. I'll abandon the change and raise a new one once ready.

Regards

Tytus Kurek"}, {'account_id': 24504, 'date': '2019-05-29 08:52:13.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning as per the discussion.'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-17 07:38:06.000000000', 'message': "Use endpoint_override in version negotiation

Change [1] introduced the usage of endpoint_filter when deciding which
endpoint to use during version negotiation. This requires properly
setting interface/region/service_type in order to properly pick the
endpoint. But, sometimes (for example in Kolla-ansible), the endpoint
url is explicitly defined. In the event of the endpoint being explicitly
defined, it should take priority here.

It should be noted that even though SessionClient extends from
keystoneauth1's adapter.LegacyJsonAdapter, the `request` function within
_make_simple_request is being called on the nested Session object, not
the Adapter itself. If it was called on the Adapter this problem
wouldn't exist, as the `endpoint_override` (or `endpoint`) kwarg passed
in to the constructor of the SessionClient would already take
precedence.

Additionally: Adds a release note to the older branch as this is a
fix that needs to be released and is worthy of change visibility
in release notes.

[1]: I42b66daea1f4397273a3f4eb1638abafb3bb28ce

Change-Id: I69dc2c88648ba1d09a9ad3ab3435662e8d1ea6ff
Related-Bug: #1818295
(cherry picked from commit 8071d5de57c728ce09d25d04c8c9fe48cd7db42e)
"}]
commit_message:
Use endpoint_override in version negotiation

Change [1] introduced the usage of endpoint_filter when deciding which
endpoint to use during version negotiation. This requires properly
setting interface/region/service_type in order to properly pick the
endpoint. But, sometimes (for example in Kolla-ansible), the endpoint
url is explicitly defined. In the event of the endpoint being explicitly
defined, it should take priority here.

It should be noted that even though SessionClient extends from
keystoneauth1's adapter.LegacyJsonAdapter, the `request` function within
_make_simple_request is being called on the nested Session object, not
the Adapter itself. If it was called on the Adapter this problem
wouldn't exist, as the `endpoint_override` (or `endpoint`) kwarg passed
in to the constructor of the SessionClient would already take
precedence.

Additionally: Adds a release note to the older branch as this is a
fix that needs to be released and is worthy of change visibility
in release notes.

[1]: I42b66daea1f4397273a3f4eb1638abafb3bb28ce

Change-Id: I69dc2c88648ba1d09a9ad3ab3435662e8d1ea6ff
Related-Bug: #1818295
(cherry picked from commit 8071d5de57c728ce09d25d04c8c9fe48cd7db42e)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-22 11:58:13.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Avoid traversing summaries in _check_traits_for_alloc_request

While doing other work, I noticed that _check_traits_for_alloc_request
traverses a list of summaries multiple time to find the "right one".
This is a classic case of a list being the wrong data structure for
the job.

The method now takes a summaries which is a dict keyed by uuid and
uses the uuid it has from the AllocationResourceRequests to find
the relevant summary.

Then, since we know the summary has the trait info we need, we don't
need to pass prov_traits to the method.

As noted in a TODO in the surrounding caller, it might make sense
to have _build_provider_summaries give us the data structure we want
but the cascade of changes from doing this was large and after a
few hours of effort was still not working.

WIP: To see that this does not negatively impact performance (one
wouldn't expect it to, but...)

Change-Id: Ic2f8f7bdc2984db2011cec329fb6f5b9efec5a0f

commit_message:
Avoid traversing summaries in _check_traits_for_alloc_request

While doing other work, I noticed that _check_traits_for_alloc_request
traverses a list of summaries multiple time to find the "right one".
This is a classic case of a list being the wrong data structure for
the job.

Instead use the request resource resource provider's id to key into
the summaries dict directly to get the relevant summary.

Then, since we know the summary has the trait info we need, we don't
need to pass prov_traits to the method.

Change-Id: Ic2f8f7bdc2984db2011cec329fb6f5b9efec5a0f

commit_message:
Use trait strings in ProviderSummary objects

When ProviderSummary objects are created and then later serialized
to JSON the traits attribute has been a list of Trait objects.

At no point in the processing of that attribute does any caller want
it to be a Trait. They are stored as TraitS but used as strings.

Therefore, this change makes it so it is a list of strings, avoiding
a few different instances of translating one way or the other, keeping
the data in the format the system wants.

Change-Id: Ia9d81ce87111ec3496d10ed254f069c04b9bdf3c

subject: Log OpenStackCloudResourceNotFound exceptions
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2, 'name': 'Monty Taylor', 'email': 'mordred@inaugust.com', 'username': 'mordred'}, {'_account_id': 6926, 'name': 'Bogdan Dobrelya', 'email': 'bdobreli@redhat.com', 'username': 'bogdando'}, {'_account_id': 10239, 'name': 'Dmitry Tantsur', 'email': 'dtantsur@protonmail.com', 'username': 'dtantsur'}, {'_account_id': 11090, 'name': 'Sergii Golovatiuk', 'email': 'sgolovat@redhat.com', 'username': 'holser'}, {'_account_id': 14352, 'name': 'Antoni Segura Puimedon', 'email': 'celebdor@gmail.com', 'username': 'toni'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]

[{'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-02-15 11:01:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-02-15 11:16:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-02-15 14:47:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-02-25 12:40:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-02-25 14:11:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2019-02-25 16:04:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I grok the problem you are trying to solve and think we should solve it.

However, we might have to dive just a little bit deeper here. The neutron path doesn't raise an exception because the current design is that if neutron doesn't work to try nova. That's because on some clouds discovery is broken and it's not clear whether neutron is functional at all.

So maybe what we want to do is either attempt to detect neutron better - or be more confident that we do a better job now of detecting neutron in the first place.

(Rackspace public cloud is a good example of a cloud where detection fails because they have neutron in the catalog but all of its methods turned off by policy by default - because INSANITY. We have a rackspace vendor profile already that asserts neutron doesn't work for rackspace, so we don't have to worry about detection logic for them - but if they're broken it's entirely possible some other clouds that sdk users are using are broken in the same way, and we wouldn't want to release a regression for them)

If we can do that, then I think we can raise here like you're attempting. I'll dive in a little bit to the logic and see if I can make a suggestion or two about where we might want to look earlier."}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-02-25 17:04:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-02-25 17:11:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Monty,

Thank you for looking into the issues. I agree that raising on neutron is very aggressive. So next patch just set a flag that will be later used in if wait clause.

However, I wanted to explain the issue. I was trying to assign floating ip use os_floating_ip ansible module. It timed out without any errors/messages. That was weird so I started digging in using pdb. During pdb debugging I dug into openstack sdk so I got an exception. It was legit as there were no connectivity between 2 networks due to issue in topology. My issue is - we shouldn't wait if both neutron and nova already failed. We should report error back to ansible (any other tool) so the error will become visible to operator so he won't need to use pdb techniques to nail down the issue in topology. Anyway, thank you very much for taking this. Feel free to update this patchset if it's needed."}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-02-26 08:42:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-02-26 08:45:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-02-28 10:49:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-02-28 11:33:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-02-28 12:18:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-05-23 15:46:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 11090, 'date': '2019-05-29 08:34:07.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

[{'created': '2019-02-15 11:01:07.000000000', 'message': "Log OpenStackCloudResourceNotFound exceptions

There are cases where router between 2 networks is not created. It means
that it's not possible to create floating ip as there are no
connectivity between networks at all. This patch allows to catch such
errors and raise instead of failing later on timeout without any
messages.

Change-Id: Ie1fc5b28ea2febd5016bc653e5879b3b705515d6
"}, {'created': '2019-02-25 12:40:37.000000000', 'message': "Log OpenStackCloudResourceNotFound exceptions

that it's not possible to create floating ip as there are no
connectivity between networks at all. It's a legit error. However, it
is not visible to software that invokes openstack sdk. This patch
raises exception on nova and neutron clauses to make error visible. Also
it skips nova case as well when skip_attach is set.

commit_message:
Log OpenStackCloudResourceNotFound exceptions

Both Neutron and Nova may fail assiging floating IP. There can be a
reason that needs further debugging from operator. As an example there
may be no connectivity between networks at all. It's a legit error. This
patch logs both neutron and nova messages. Also, it raises
attach_ip_failed flag that helps not to wait for floating ip when both
methods already failed.

Change-Id: Ie1fc5b28ea2febd5016bc653e5879b3b705515d6

commit_message:
Relax checksum fields validation

In stein, ironic added the new os_hash_algo and os_hash_value checksum
fields provided by glance, but the checksum field is still mandatory,
which is inconvenient for standalone use case.

We could relax the checksum checking and proceed as long as there is at
least one of checksum mechanism available.

Change-Id: Ia90197416f76ada0422681044a16f1c07d7049a1
Story: 2005773
Task: 33490

[{'created': '2019-05-27 07:07:43.000000000', 'message': "Optimize NovaClusterDataModelCollector.add_instance_node

This does two things:

1. Rather than make an API call per server on the host,
   get all of the servers in a single API call by
   filtering on the host. The os-hypervisors API results
   to use make this require a bit of refactoring since
   get_compute_node_by_name does not have the service
   entry in it and get_compute_node_by_id does not have the
   servers entry in it. A TODO is added to clean that up
   with a single call to os-hypervisors once we have the
   support in python-novaclient.

2. Pulls get_node_by_uuid() out of the loop.

A test is added for the nova_helper get_instance_list method
since one did not exist before.

The fake compute node mocks in test_nova_cdmc_execute are
also cleaned up since, as noted above, get_compute_node_by_name
and get_compute_node_by_id don't both return all the details.

Change-Id: Ifd9f83c2f399d4c1765b0c520f4d5a62ad0f5fbd
(cherry picked from commit fdea38fb060e1b48b457332077db4802c49e17f8)
"}]
commit_message:
Optimize NovaClusterDataModelCollector.add_instance_node

This does two things:

1. Rather than make an API call per server on the host,
   get all of the servers in a single API call by
   filtering on the host. The os-hypervisors API results
   to use make this require a bit of refactoring since
   get_compute_node_by_name does not have the service
   entry in it and get_compute_node_by_id does not have the
   servers entry in it. A TODO is added to clean that up
   with a single call to os-hypervisors once we have the
   support in python-novaclient.

2. Pulls get_node_by_uuid() out of the loop.

A test is added for the nova_helper get_instance_list method
since one did not exist before.

The fake compute node mocks in test_nova_cdmc_execute are
also cleaned up since, as noted above, get_compute_node_by_name
and get_compute_node_by_id don't both return all the details.

Change-Id: Ifd9f83c2f399d4c1765b0c520f4d5a62ad0f5fbd
(cherry picked from commit fdea38fb060e1b48b457332077db4802c49e17f8)

commit_message:
Fix disk multiattach with VirtualBox 6

Starting with version 6.0, the behavior of VirtualBox with regards to
disk multiattach changed.

The result are error messages like:
  VBoxManage: error: Cannot change type for medium '<base_disk_path>':
  the media type 'MultiAttach' can only be used on media registered
  with a machine that was created with VirtualBox 4.0 or later

The new code should work for both VirtualBox 6 and older versions.

The workaround suggests that we may not be using the VirtualBox volumes
the way they are meant to be used, but with scant documentation out
there rewriting the volume logic may result in no improvement at all,
so let's leave it at that for the time being.

backport: rocky queens pike ocata

Closes-Bug: 1817584

Change-Id: I9307d2e0f077539c118f540a9b0a4358e4f3b459
(cherry picked from commit e4dec38469acdac6f9e408ac8612e709405cd998)

commit_message:
Fix disk multiattach with VirtualBox 6

Starting with version 6.0, the behavior of VirtualBox with regards to
disk multiattach changed.

The result are error messages like:
  VBoxManage: error: Cannot change type for medium '<base_disk_path>':
  the media type 'MultiAttach' can only be used on media registered
  with a machine that was created with VirtualBox 4.0 or later

The new code should work for both VirtualBox 6 and older versions.

The workaround suggests that we may not be using the VirtualBox volumes
the way they are meant to be used, but with scant documentation out
there rewriting the volume logic may result in no improvement at all,
so let's leave it at that for the time being.

backport: rocky queens pike ocata

Closes-Bug: 1817584

Change-Id: I9307d2e0f077539c118f540a9b0a4358e4f3b459
(cherry picked from commit e4dec38469acdac6f9e408ac8612e709405cd998)

commit_message:
Add domain and no-ntp options to ipaclient

Two options have proven useful for deployers.
--domain: To specify the IdM DNS domain in cases where the client is
  not in the same DNS domain as the IdM server
--no-ntp: To ensure that the idm-client-install does not change the
  NTP settings when they have already been set by puppet.

The patch adds both these options.

Change-Id: I88075174dfffe4117c8ccc31f28ed9f43bf8b4e7
(cherry picked from commit edfbeae9182108be15ad020ec26167934525eb57)

Remove dead code from NovaClusterDataModelCollector

The _add_virtual_layer and _add_virtual_servers methods
have not been used since Ic4659d1f18af181203439a8bf1b38805ff34c309
in Stein so this change removes them.

Starting with version 6.0, the behavior of VirtualBox with regards to
disk multiattach changed.

The result are error messages like:
  VBoxManage: error: Cannot change type for medium '<base_disk_path>':
  the media type 'MultiAttach' can only be used on media registered
  with a machine that was created with VirtualBox 4.0 or later

The new code should work for both VirtualBox 6 and older versions.

the way they are meant to be used, but with scant documentation out
there rewriting the volume logic may result in no improvement at all,
so let's leave it at that for the time being.

backport: rocky queens pike ocata

commit_message:
Fix disk multiattach with VirtualBox 6

Starting with version 6.0, the behavior of VirtualBox with regards to
disk multiattach changed.

The result are error messages like:
  VBoxManage: error: Cannot change type for medium '<base_disk_path>':
  the media type 'MultiAttach' can only be used on media registered
  with a machine that was created with VirtualBox 4.0 or later

The new code should work for both VirtualBox 6 and older versions.

The workaround suggests that we may not be using the VirtualBox volumes
the way they are meant to be used, but with scant documentation out
there rewriting the volume logic may result in no improvement at all,
so let's leave it at that for the time being.

backport: rocky queens pike ocata

Closes-Bug: 1817584

Change-Id: I9307d2e0f077539c118f540a9b0a4358e4f3b459
(cherry picked from commit e4dec38469acdac6f9e408ac8612e709405cd998)

commit_message:
Update migration notification

_post_live_migration[1] runs on the source host and calls
post_live_migration_at_destination on the dest host which
emits the instance.live_migration_post_dest.end notification:[2]
But it's not the last notification for the live migration operation.
so we should use instance.live_migration_post.end instead of
instance.live_migration_post_dest.end notification.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/daa2ac2287df12dfdee532d66ef97a03350ca6af/nova/compute/manager.py#L6907
[2]https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/daa2ac2287df12dfdee532d66ef97a03350ca6af/nova/compute/manager.py#L7035

Change-Id: Id1e2d98f56d5a95d49e32f98d2910660b9f48ce6

commit_message:
Add multipath to nova-compute AppArmor profile

Deploying nova-compute with apparmor in enforce mode causes it to fail
to attach volumes with multipath. This patch fixes it by updating the
nova-compute apparmor profile to include paths and binaries needed for
multipath.

Change-Id: Icc2d187fa3dd63e0930d57a87e7a60ff386f0032
Closes-bug: #1826467
(cherry picked from commit 40914493c7be88a1c3cd80c937d65e044301c24b)

commit_message:
Added verification to ensure iscsid is running

Currently, the charm does not verify if iscsid is installed or
running. This patch adds those verifications on install and
update hooks.

Closes-bug: #1816435

Change-Id: I23992832a82557f406999427fe8d151f6a2b63af

commit_message:
Enable Glance image signature verification feature

The rationale behind this change is to allow the use of the glance image
signature verification feature.
In order to do so, it is necessary to be able to relate the barbican
charm to the glance charm. This change add a `provides` interface to the
charm.

Change-Id: I72fa2f73041479650a448497bad5ffa7655ce459
Closes-Bug: 1811067

commit_message:
Use AuthMethod context

Rather than use hard coded auth methods, use the protocal named passed
over the keystone-fid-service-provider relation.

Also, when using federation do not allow the "external" method as they
are mutually exclusive.

Change-Id: I08f0632630d7f0e8d2d7ddb057e02f9febf9ad6f
Closes-Bug: #1828015
Closes-Bug: #1828018
(cherry picked from commit a103c15e40612b4c2c801543896bda4bbd5396f0)

commit_message:
Replace nova vendor metadata code

Two generic contexts to handle nova vendor metadata have
been implemented in charm-helpers. So, replace the existing
one here in order to simplify and unify the implementation
across all charms that handle vendor metadata.

Change-Id: I2a802c763f2f4403a6dfb17575aa742ca8072e96
Related-Bug: #1777714

Hi Alex. Shouldn't this be covered by a unit test?"}, {'account_id': 30413, 'date': '2019-05-26 05:41:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2019-05-26 17:21:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Rodrigo, re: unit test, probably it should've been covered, but wasn't.  I could lock it down, but unit tests for types quickly become extremely onerous -- it's what type checkers should be doing.  If this get's nacked, then I will add a test (although no tests exist for class/context at present)."}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2019-05-29 07:06:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-25 16:24:13.000000000', 'message': 'Fix change of return type in NeutronAMQPContext.__call__()

A recent change means that a branch returns None for an empty context
when the parent class returns {} for an empty context.  This changes the
return on that branch back to the empty {} returned from the parent.

Change-Id: Ia59c2b2402c1ade94c9b4addc4c7b9b8c1569210
'}]
commit_message:
Fix change of return type in NeutronAMQPContext.__call__()

A recent change means that a branch returns None for an empty context
when the parent class returns {} for an empty context.  This changes the
return on that branch back to the empty {} returned from the parent.

Change-Id: Ia59c2b2402c1ade94c9b4addc4c7b9b8c1569210

commit_message:
sync sql fixtures from neutron

This patch updates the sql fixtures in neutron_lib.fixtures to
match their implementation in neutron. This is necessary due to some
issues with the existing fixtures in neutron-lib. The fixtures are
still marked private as we'll need to test them again before
making them public for consumption.

Sample consumption patch: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/657887/

Change-Id: I3e1ed2374125f2ac1e57db70bf206fdbeb3f82e4

(5 comments)

I think this change should be done *after* the current Cinder API changes we are doing. In terms of priority.

We are missing lots of details in the spec around why this so important to these users. What are they actually trying to do, or not do.

The implementation details don't seem very clear right now. There is a lot of os-brick talk, but generally I think this is a libvirt specific thing, can it perform the rebase between the two volumes."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-27 14:28:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Allow first address in an IPv6 subnet as valid unicast

When looking at the RFC [1], there's no mention that this can't be the
gateway address.  Permit it.

[1] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4291#section-2.6.1

Change-Id: I3f2905c2c4fca02406dfa3c801c166c14389ba41
Fixes-Bug: #1682094
(cherry picked from commit 1916bc5c0627ca24e312ca55ea62c8df7eb8f158)

commit_message:
Publish baremetal endpoint via mdns

This change adds an option to publish the endpoint via mDNS on start
up and clean it up on tear down.

Story: #2005393
Task: #30383
Change-Id: I55d2e7718a23cde111eaac4e431588184cb16bda

commit_message:
Add upper-constraints enforcement for local reqs

This adds the use of upper constraints in our tox environments. Jobs
like openstack-tox-py27 have started failing due to trying to install
lib versions that only support Python 3.

The 'generate' target keeps the unconstrained deps since we actually do
need the latest installed for that.

NOTE(dmllr): updated install_command to include local constraints file

Change-Id: I2598503c2d4397d7efbb03a76df9a4e91dd0c1cf
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 8bad9fe19d09eb2e49fd44b92c57ee5acf85b558)
(cherry picked from commit ab0875127bd23cf18c549440b9e0130d5162b73d)
(cherry picked from commit f707d12d81e68a8a7c568a3bda0779b1db8839ba)
(cherry picked from commit 31237956f2512035d992315c58caa9d1df2ca6d2)

[{'created': '2019-04-18 03:43:22.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Use a typemap file instead of symlinks for tags

To support manifest lists, the response for requesting a tagged
manifest will need to return different contents based on the
content-type requested. Representing a tag as a symlink to the
manifest directory is not flexible enough for this need.

This change switches over to a type-map[1] based implementation so
that future changes can add entries to different files based on the
content-type. Whenever any write operation is performed on an image,
any existing symlink based tags will be migrated to a typemap.

WIP until there are unit tests.

[1] https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/mod_negotiation.html#typemaps
Change-Id: I0e56e1d74ef8468f1b89da5329a8f1ced711c0f3
'}, {'created': '2019-05-08 01:28:23.000000000', 'message': 'Use a typemap file instead of symlinks for tags

Change-Id: I0e56e1d74ef8468f1b89da5329a8f1ced711c0f3
'}]
commit_message:
Use a typemap file instead of symlinks for tags

To support manifest lists, the response for requesting a tagged
manifest will need to return different contents based on the
content-type requested. Representing a tag as a symlink to the
manifest directory is not flexible enough for this need.

This change switches over to a type-map[1] based implementation so
that future changes can add entries to different files based on the
content-type. Whenever any write operation is performed on an image,
any existing symlink based tags will be migrated to a typemap.

[1] https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/mod/mod_negotiation.html#typemaps
Change-Id: I0e56e1d74ef8468f1b89da5329a8f1ced711c0f3

messages: [{'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-05-09 01:03:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-05-09 02:09:06.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to cap-hacking'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-10-16 11:27:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-05-28 11:29:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2019-05-28 11:59:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-05-29 03:28:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:\n\nrecheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-09 01:03:38.000000000', 'message': 'Gate fix: Cap hacking to avoid gate failure

hacking is not capped in g-r and it is in
blacklist for requirement as hacking new version
can break the gate jobs.

Hacking can break gate jobs because of various
reasons:
- There might be new rule addition in hacking
- Some rules becomes default from non-default
- Updates in pycodestyle etc

That was the main reason it was not added in g-r
auto sync also. Most of the project maintained the
compatible and cap the hacking version in
test-requirements.txt and update to new version when
project is ready. Bumping new version might need code
fix also on project side depends on what new in that
version.

If project does not have cap the hacking version then,
there is possibility of gate failure whenever new hacking
version is released by QA team.

Example of such failure in recent release of hacking 1.1.0
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-May/130282.html

Change-Id: I4172dd0c905760dd84e5ff60d3fa052aae794edf

commit_message:
Gate fix: Cap hacking to avoid gate failure

hacking is not capped in g-r and it is in
blacklist for requirement as hacking new version
can break the gate jobs.

Hacking can break gate jobs because of various
reasons:
- There might be new rule addition in hacking
- Some rules becomes default from non-default
- Updates in pycodestyle etc

That was the main reason it was not added in g-r
auto sync also. Most of the project maintained the
compatible and cap the hacking version in
test-requirements.txt and update to new version when
project is ready. Bumping new version might need code
fix also on project side depends on what new in that
version.

If project does not have cap the hacking version then,
there is possibility of gate failure whenever new hacking
version is released by QA team.

Example of such failure in recent release of hacking 1.1.0
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-May/130282.html

Change-Id: I4172dd0c905760dd84e5ff60d3fa052aae794edf

Some people are still disappointed by the fact that application
credentials are not project-owned. This patch adds a note about why this
decision was made and adds a recommendation to overcome it.

Change-Id: I546bdc55937948d51154f4a4aecec08b4e4fd58d

commit_message:
Add note about application credential ownership

Some people are still disappointed by the fact that application
credentials are not project-owned. This patch adds a note about why this
decision was made and adds a recommendation to overcome it.

Change-Id: I546bdc55937948d51154f4a4aecec08b4e4fd58d

commit_message:
Fix live-migration when glance image deleted

When block live-migration is run on instance with
a deleted glance image, image.cache() is called
without specyfing instance disk size parameter,
preventing the resize of disk on the target host.

Change-Id: Id0f05bb1275cc816d98b662820e02eae25dc57a3
Closes-Bug: #1829000

commit_message:
Remove 'etc/nova/cells.json'

This was added in change I7046ce55a0a294293c1b1a5fb0f092aeb891ee01 as an
example for how one could configure a cells v1 deployment via a JSON
file. It can be removed now.

Part of blueprint remove-cells-v1

Change-Id: I3235f38c432f1dbafde167ec0e856abe7a38aa8a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove conductor_api and _last_host_check from manager.py

conductor_api and _last_host_check are not
used in manager.py, so this is to remove them.

Part of blueprint remove-cells-v1

Change-Id: I9f52b84e00c92d7734690d115e2b5e8f9c788f15

commit_message:
Remove 'instance_update_from_api'

This was being called within the 'Instance' object. Remove it in its
entirety, given that nothing should be calling it now.

This also allows us to remove some special handling of the
'Instance.cell_name' field, given that nothing should be setting this
anymore.

Part of blueprint remove-cells-v1

Change-Id: I4f2ddf523d9ebfbc6f21a64687b2edb33d0ed1df
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Retiring TripleO-UI

The TripleO-UI related tripleo-ci stuff is being removed because
of the retirement of TripleO-UI.

Change-Id: I1a7ca305a6885c5faeea6db874edf84cf91f6ddd

[{'created': '2019-05-21 06:45:31.000000000', 'message': 'Do not set port addresses on LSP while port not bound

FIP that points to VIP port could not have addresses
specified [1]. Router pipeline will try to resolve
ARP requests internally from LSP instead looking for
actual MAC address from LSP where VIP exists at this moment.

Lets not set this address till the port is bound.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1707241

Change-Id: I36261701be393584ad4b00ced96273736339b03c
Closes-Bug: #1789686
(cherry picked from commit 33fd553158a96b4dc40c66acf050fa7f91227dec)
'}]
commit_message:
Do not set port addresses on LSP while port not bound

FIP that points to VIP port could not have addresses
specified [1]. Router pipeline will try to resolve
ARP requests internally from LSP instead looking for
actual MAC address from LSP where VIP exists at this moment.

Lets not set this address till the port is bound.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1707241

Change-Id: I36261701be393584ad4b00ced96273736339b03c
Closes-Bug: #1789686
(cherry picked from commit 33fd553158a96b4dc40c66acf050fa7f91227dec)

commit_message:
Wait to ipv6 accept_ra be really changed by L3 agent

In functional tests for L3 HA agent, like e.g.
L3HATestFailover.test_ha_router_failover
it may happen that L3 agent will not change ipv6 accept_ra
knob and test fails because it checks that only once just
after router state is change.

This patch fixes that race by adding wait for 60 seconds to
ipv6 accept_ra change.

Conflicts:
    neutron/tests/functional/agent/l3/framework.py

Change-Id: I459ce4b791c27b1e3d977e0de9fbdb21a8a379f5
Closes-Bug: #1829889
(cherry picked from commit 62b2f2b1b1e2d8c0c2ffc1fd2ae9467eb2c1ef07)

commit_message:
Add port_forwarding to devstack plugin

This commit adds possibility to configure fip port_forwarding
service plugin and l3 extension with devstack plugin.

Change-Id: If01dd1db1b4a44ba2f7e2d8f8326e331f9dc79e9
(cherry picked from commit 4d50adb5923896deb2607a5a21d492794c21d8c2)

subject: Allow [a-zA-Z0-9_-]{1,64} for request group suffix
messages:
[{'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-06 17:58:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2019-05-06 18:18:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-06 18:23:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(8 comments)

placement.schemas.allocation_candidate._GROUP_PAT_FMT would need to be changed to make this work from the API.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-06 18:24:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-06 19:17:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-06 19:18:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-06 19:20:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Cool, this design wfm. Obviously still a WIP so not voting.'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2019-05-06 19:34:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

Much better. Still need better error messages for the pattern failures, though.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-06 19:39:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-06 20:38:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)

> Much better. Still need better error messages for the pattern
 > failures, though.

From the API side the error message that a client who does a bag resoruces* will see something like:

'resources1a' does not match any of the regexes: '^member_of([A-Z0-9_-]{1,32})?$', '^required([A-Z0-9_-]{1,32})?$', '^resources([A-Z0-9_-]{1,32})?$'

That is: the 400 will be raised by schema validation, not the code in placement.lib (which has the generic message).

I can adjust one of the tests to be more clear about the error message so where it happens is more clear.

What I think we may want to consider (if we agree on it):

Tune this up, fix the docs, merge it independent of anythings else (and without a microversion).

Then, when we implement required without resources, _that_ would be a microversion.

It doesn't really matter, making a microversion is no big deal. What I'm more interested in is making sure we don't couple changes into a big stack."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-06 20:42:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-06 20:46:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Will let this sit while we resolve the discussion on ps3.

This change adds some tests to confirm the error message a bit better.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-10 22:40:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-05-13 16:13:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-16 11:29:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

One potential issue with limiting this to just uppercase is that we tend to use uuid in their lowercase form.

Is it annoying to require people to do a transformation when creating a group name?

(comment within is a note to self that I apparently made weeks ago and then didn't save, but is still relevant)"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-16 12:32:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-16 12:36:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Couple of issues to decide before we say groovy on this:

* See my comment on ps4 about limitations of upper case
* I've done this without a microversion and explained why in the release note. This may not be satisfactory for everyone. We should reach wide agreement if this is okay."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-16 13:40:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

> Couple of issues to decide before we say groovy on this:

We should have an approved spec first too, I would imagine.

> See my comment on ps4 about limitations of upper case

Makes sense to me, and so does Ed's rationale about distinguishing via case. I wouldn't oppose either way, but if I had to choose...

I agree it would be nice if suffixes were always easily human-readable, but this is first and foremost an API for machines to talk to. Machines don't have trouble distinguishing resources1 from resourcesI from resourcesl etc. And the consumer of the API is still in control of making suffixes human-readable if and as they wish (like by using delimiters, or themselves sticking to always using uppercase). So I say we should target for common, non-pathological cases that we know about, and it sounds like lowercase UUIDs are in that category. So allowing lowercase seems like the better choice.

> I've done this without a microversion and explained why in the release note. This may not be satisfactory for everyone. We should reach wide agreement if this is okay.

Yeah, the counterargument being that things that would have previously resulted in 400s would now get further and possibly "succeed". That kind of implies that someone's counting on getting a 400 from a bogus queryparam, which seems unlikely. Given where we are in the world right now, I'm inclined to be liberal with this and let it happen without a microversion.

I am going to downvote on the spec issue, though. Normally for API changes (which this is, microversion or no) a formal spec is required. But in this case I could probably get behind the equivalent of a "specless blueprint", however that works in sb. Extract (and update) the text currently in the spec draft [1] into {what? - a task? a story?} and agree to approve that (how? what's the equivalent to bp approval in sb?).

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658510/2/doc/source/specs/train/approved/2005575-nested-magic.rst@44'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-16 14:33:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > > Couple of issues to decide before we say groovy on this:
 > 
 > We should have an approved spec first too, I would imagine.

I'm gonna go with "not really". Part of the reason for not doing this on a microversion is get it done ahead of and out sync with any of the other nested-magic related changes. But see also below for a bit more detail.

 > So I say we should target for common,
 > non-pathological cases that we know about, and it sounds like
 > lowercase UUIDs are in that category. So allowing lowercase seems
 > like the better choice.

I'm leaning this way too, but will until Ed and others can weigh in.

 > Given where we
 > are in the world right now, I'm inclined to be liberal with this
 > and let it happen without a microversion.

Pretty much what I was thinking.

 > I am going to downvote on the spec issue, though. Normally for API
 > changes (which this is, microversion or no) a formal spec is
 > required.

That's a nova rule. Placement doesn't have a rule yet other than what's in the docs at https://docs.openstack.org/placement/latest/contributor/contributing.html#new-features where we say "Once there is a clear need for a change, a story should be created in StoryBoard with a tag of rfe. Placement team members will evaluate the story to determine if a spec is required. If it is, a task to create the spec will be added to the story. At this time there are no hard and fast rules on what will require a spec."

In this case I've interpreted that to mean: for the simple pieces of this that are relatively well understood we don't need a spec beyond the story (2005575). The spec is for the parts that are confusing (of which there a fair few confusing pieces and thus the spec is a great place to build agreement) but the story is the ultimate authority and tracker.

 > and agree to approve that (how? what's
 > the equivalent to bp approval in sb?).

Until we have a situation where we have too many people trying to do too much work to be able to review it well (which is part (but not all) of what led to the nova processes I'd hope that the equivalent of "approval" is talking about it.

If we need a signal (I'm not sure we do given the small size of the team and the presence of aide-mmoires like the pupdate) in storyboard that an 'rfe' story has been approved it is the presence of tasks created by cores.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-16 16:03:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

> Placement team members will evaluate the story to determine if a spec is required. 

Yeah, I guess that's what's happening here.

As long as

a) The design outline is documented cohesively (so having to read a disjointed chain of patch set comments and deltas doesn't count) with motivations for decisions made (ditto)

b) That content doesn't get "too long for a story" (I'll know it when I see it?)

I'm fine with not requiring a spec.

I think probably "microversion requires spec" is a good rule of thumb to go forward with in general, though. (Doesn't imply the converse.)'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2019-05-16 20:53:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-16 21:54:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-17 09:36:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Workflow-1

(2 comments)

Thanks for the thoughtful reviews.

I'll make a new version that:

* [A-Za-z0-9_-]{1,64} (and case sensitive)
* microversioned
* tunes the docs appropriately

There are two questions about preferences within on which input is desired."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-17 16:04:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-20 16:41:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-20 22:06:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

(5 comments)

Rockin.'}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-05-20 22:58:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Is there a corresponding Nova patch or spec? If not, it will be good to add words on how all this gets used. Reference: [1]

1. If a flavor request group (RG) has suffix '_foo', and a Cyborg device profile references that, it is the operator's responsibility to embed that device profile only in a flavor that has the suffix '_foo'. Correct?
2. How would the 'same_subtree' clause be specified? As part of the flavor? Could it be in a Neutron port request or Cyborg device profile?

[1] https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2005575"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-21 10:07:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-21 10:26:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-21 13:49:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> Is there a corresponding Nova patch or spec?

No, there's not.

> If not, it will be good to add words on how all this gets used.

I agree. We have a vague hand-wavey use case in the spec [2]. However, anything more specific doesn't really belong in placement IMO.

> 1. If a flavor request group (RG) has suffix '_foo', and a Cyborg device profile references that, it is the operator's responsibility to embed that device profile only in a flavor that has the suffix '_foo'. Correct?

Sort of. See below.

> 2. How would the 'same_subtree' clause be specified? As part of the flavor? Could it be in a Neutron port request or Cyborg device profile?

This (affinity via same_subtree) is the main motivator for this feature I believe. But I anticipate it being algorithmic, based on a naming convention for the suffixes, rather than embedded explicitly in flavor/device_profile/image metadata. So the flavor request group for e.g. VCPU resources should not use the *same* request group suffix as the device_profile group for an accelerator resource - that would try to land them on the same provider, which would be bad. Rather, we would achieve affinity by using an agreed-upon common substring (pattern).

For example, if your flavor said:

 VCPU = 5
 hw:numa_nodes = 2
 hw:numa_cpus.0 = 0,1
 hw:numa_cpus.1 = 2,3,4

we would translate that to two request groups:

 resources_COMPUTE_NUMA0=VCPU:2,
 resources_COMPUTE_NUMA1=VCPU:3

Now let's say your device profile wants one accelerator affined to each of two NUMA nodes; it could say:

 resources_ACCEL_NUMA0=FPGA:1,
 resources_ACCEL_NUMA1=FPGA:1

And based on the naming convention (.endswith(_NUMA*) kind of thing) we (n-sch) would add (resourceless) request groups for:

 required_AFFINITY_NUMA0=I_AM_A_NUMA_NODE,
 required_AFFINITY_NUMA1=I_AM_A_NUMA_NODE

and same_subtree params to tie each of the groupings together:

 same_subtree=_COMPUTE_NUMA0,_ACCEL_NUMA0,_AFFINITY_NUMA0,
 same_subtree=_COMPUTE_NUMA1,_ACCEL_NUMA1,_AFFINITY_NUMA1

> [1] https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2005575
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658510/2/doc/source/specs/train/approved/2005575-nested-magic.rst@46"}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2019-05-21 15:18:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-05-23 16:22:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

The overall design direction looks good to me, but I have reviewed the implementation details yet, hence the +1 only.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-05-28 09:17:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)

Looks good. I have a question in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/657419/7/api-ref/source/parameters.yaml@169 if that is answered then I'm +2 on this.

Cheers,
gibi"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-05-28 09:54:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-28 13:24:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-06 17:58:04.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Allow [A-Za-z0-9_-]{1,32} for request group suffix

This does the simplest change to move from numeric suffixes
to strings suffixes that can be 32 chars longs made from '-',
'_', and alphanumeric.

This is a WIP because:

* docs need to be updated

* We need to make some decisions about:

   * Do we need a microversion for this? Strictly speaking we do
     because things that were previously a 400 will now sometimes
     work. On the other hand, stuff that already worked will
     continue to work without additional signalling.

   * If we do a microversion how much of the large collection of
     nested-related improvements should be in the same microversion?

   * See the TODO within about error messages with poorly formed
     grouping params.

Nothing is done here about allowing required without a resources.
That will be a separate patch.

Story: 2005575
Task: 30781
Change-Id: Ia44b0922d151695d406883262e891bd932536f38
"}, {'created': '2019-05-06 19:17:29.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Allow [A-Za-z0-9_-]{1,32} for request group suffix

'_', and upper-case alphanumeric. The format is shared between
schema and RequestGroup parsing.

This is a WIP because:

* docs need to be updated

* We need to make some decisions about:

   * Do we need a microversion for this? Strictly speaking we do
     because things that were previously a 400 will now sometimes
     work. On the other hand, stuff that already worked will
     continue to work without additional signalling.

     Looking at the changed (or removed) tests will give some
     insight into the impact of the changes.

   * If we do a microversion how much of the large collection of
     nested-related improvements should be in the same microversion?

   * See the TODO within about error messages with poorly formed
     grouping params.

Nothing is done here about allowing required without a resources.
That will be a separate patch.

Story: 2005575
Task: 30781
Change-Id: Ia44b0922d151695d406883262e891bd932536f38
"}, {'created': '2019-05-16 12:32:13.000000000', 'message': 'Allow [A-Z0-9_-]{1,64} for request group suffix

This does the simplest change to move from numeric suffixes
to strings suffixes that can be 64 chars longs made from '-',
'_', and upper-case alphanumeric. The format is shared between
schema and RequestGroup parsing.

Docs and and api-ref are updated to changed from "numbered" to
"suffixed" or "granular" groups.

A release note is added, including a note on why this isn't
being done in a microversion.

Nothing is done here about allowing required without a resources.
That will be a separate patch.

commit_message:
Allow [a-zA-Z0-9_-]{1,64} for request group suffix

Add a 1.33 microversion to move from numeric suffixes to string
suffixes that can be 64 chars longs made from '-', '_', and
mixed-case alphanumeric. The format is shared between schema
and RequestGroup parsing.

Docs, api-ref, api history and microversion upper limit are updated
to indicate the new form in the new microversion.

A release note is added.

Story: 2005575
Task: 30781
Change-Id: Ia44b0922d151695d406883262e891bd932536f38

commit_message:
Enable fail-fast on the gate queue

Zuul recently added fail-fast[1] as a new option for project
pipelines. With this set, if any one of the voting jobs fails, zuul
will report a build failure immediately and abort the remaining
jobs.

This patch enables fail-fast on the gate pipeline as any one
failing job means the patch will not merge.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/652764

Change-Id: I5e8cbe1f4eafd18e67b5b6914f5d459fb157a3a1

commit_message:
Add domain and no-ntp options to ipaclient

Two options have proven useful for deployers.
--domain: To specify the IdM DNS domain in cases where the client is
  not in the same DNS domain as the IdM server
--no-ntp: To ensure that the idm-client-install does not change the
  NTP settings when they have already been set by puppet.

The patch adds both these options.

Change-Id: I88075174dfffe4117c8ccc31f28ed9f43bf8b4e7
(cherry picked from commit edfbeae9182108be15ad020ec26167934525eb57)

commit_message:
Add use_required_attribute = False in some form

When an element is required and hidden,
the browser will report an error when submitting the form.

Here is the code location where Django adds the required attribute to the element:
https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/forms/boundfield.py#L221-L222

Change-Id: Ib30b7e9efb4031454f0ba3cd9588ed829953bb67

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-27 00:29:51.000000000', 'message': 'Support multiple external networks in L3 agent

Change [1] removed the deprecated option external_network_bridge. Per
commit message in change [2], "l3 agent can handle any networks by
setting the neutron parameter external_network_bridge and
gateway_external_network_id to empty". So the consequence of [1] was to
introduce a regression whereby multiple external networks are not
supported by the L3 agent anymore.

This change proposes a new simplified rule. If
gateway_external_network_id is defined, that is the network that the L3
agent will use. If not and multiple external networks exist, the L3
agent will handle any of them.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/567369/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/59359

Change-Id: Idd766bd069eda85ab6876a78b8b050ee5ab66cf6

commit_message:
Support multiple external networks in L3 agent

Change [1] removed the deprecated option external_network_bridge. Per
commit message in change [2], "l3 agent can handle any networks by
setting the neutron parameter external_network_bridge and
gateway_external_network_id to empty". So the consequence of [1] was to
introduce a regression whereby multiple external networks are not
supported by the L3 agent anymore.

This change proposes a new simplified rule. If
gateway_external_network_id is defined, that is the network that the L3
agent will use. If not and multiple external networks exist, the L3
agent will handle any of them.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/567369/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/59359

Change-Id: Idd766bd069eda85ab6876a78b8b050ee5ab66cf6
Closes-Bug: #1824571

1) is there a reason: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/644388/59/postgresql/templates/bin/_start.sh.tpl@21 has not been adressed?

2) can we see the dockerfile added to the images repo, so that it may be rebuilt/audited.

3) I'd really like to see no regression in the ability of password rotation."}, {'account_id': 28718, 'date': '2019-05-06 14:10:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 76:

> 1) is there a reason: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/644388/59/postgresql/templates/bin/_start.sh.tpl@21
 > has not been adressed?
 > 
 > 2) can we see the dockerfile added to the images repo, so that it
 > may be rebuilt/audited.
 > 
 > 3) I'd really like to see no regression in the ability of password
 > rotation.

1) Using _values_template_renderer renders the values from values.yaml as a string, rather than yaml. Patroni didn't like that and needs yaml objects. I moved most of the configurable parts to the values.yaml, but most of the hardcoded values still left are things that won't need to be changed, so there's no point in cluttering up the values.yaml file.

2) Currently working on getting the image published to the nc-dockerfiles repo. Dustin Specker has been doing a lot of work in the repo to make it more generic so I don't think the repo is ready for full time use quite yet.

3) Password rotation has been taken care of: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/656677"}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2019-05-06 14:29:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 59:

> > 1) is there a reason: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/644388/59/postgresql/templates/bin/_start.sh.tpl@21
 > > has not been adressed?
 > >
 > > 2) can we see the dockerfile added to the images repo, so that it
 > > may be rebuilt/audited.
 > >
 > > 3) I'd really like to see no regression in the ability of
 > password
 > > rotation.
 > 
 > 1) Using _values_template_renderer renders the values from
 > values.yaml as a string, rather than yaml. Patroni didn't like that
 > and needs yaml objects. I moved most of the configurable parts to
 > the values.yaml, but most of the hardcoded values still left are
 > things that won't need to be changed, so there's no point in
 > cluttering up the values.yaml file.

Please see: https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm-infra/blob/master/helm-toolkit/templates/snippets/_values_template_renderer.tpl#L31-L33 - bear in mind a large part of the ratonalle her is to allow read-only fileystsmes in conatiners - if you still wish to cat out config files please move to an init container.

 > 2) Currently working on getting the image published to the
 > nc-dockerfiles repo. Dustin Specker has been doing a lot of work in
 > the repo to make it more generic so I don't think the repo is ready
 > for full time use quite yet.

The image should be in the openstack-helm-images repo https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm-images as are all other images used in OSH charts. 

 > 3) Password rotation has been taken care of: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/656677

Great - though could that be included in this PS?"}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2019-05-06 15:45:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 76: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

We really need to address the handling of the configuration file here.  I'm not comfortable having the configuration file generated by the entrypoint override for the container here.  I'd also like to see a corresponding change bringing this image into openstack-helm-images"}, {'account_id': 28718, 'date': '2019-05-06 15:54:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 76:

 > - bear in mind a large part of the ratonalle her is to allow

 > images used in OSH charts.
 > 
 > > 3) Password rotation has been taken care of: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/656677
 > 
 > Great - though could that be included in this PS?

1) I realized that I had been looking at the _values_template_renderer function wrong. I'll get a PS ready and fix the start script.
2) The only difference between the image I'm using here is that the upstream patroni image uses v11 of postgres but internally we use v9.5. I'm not really sure if we want to maintain a secondary upstream image were the only difference is that the postgres versions.
3) Will merge the two patchsets"}, {'account_id': 28718, 'date': '2019-05-06 15:54:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 76:
