'}, {'created': '2019-04-29 16:00:02.000000000', 'message': 'Patroni inclusion work for HA Postgres

This patchset aims to add HA Clustering support for Postgres. HA Clustering
includes automatic failover in the event of the database going down and
replication of the database across the cluster.

To achieve this clustering we used a project called
[Patroni](https://github.com/zalando/patroni) which offers HA clustering
support for Postgres.

- Picking up patchset: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/591663

Co-authored-by: Tony Sorrentino <as1413@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Randeep Jalli <rj2083@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>
Change-Id: I721b745017dc1ea7ae05dfd9f8d5dd08d0965985
'}, {'created': '2019-04-29 16:48:54.000000000', 'message': 'Patroni inclusion work for HA Postgres

This patchset aims to add HA Clustering support for Postgres. HA Clustering
includes automatic failover in the event of the database going down and
replication of the database across the cluster.

To achieve this clustering we used a project called
[Patroni](https://github.com/zalando/patroni) which offers HA clustering
support for Postgres.

- Picking up patchset: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/591663

Co-authored-by: Tony Sorrentino <as1413@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Randeep Jalli <rj2083@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>
Change-Id: I721b745017dc1ea7ae05dfd9f8d5dd08d0965985
'}, {'created': '2019-04-29 18:26:14.000000000', 'message': 'Patroni inclusion work for HA Postgres

This patchset aims to add HA Clustering support for Postgres. HA Clustering
provides automatic failover in the event of the database going down in addition
to keeping replicas of the database for rebuilding in the even of a node
going down. To achieve this clustering we use
[Patroni](https://github.com/zalando/patroni) which offers HA clustering
support for Postgres.

Patroni is a daemon that runs in the background and keeps track of which
node in your cluster is currently the leader node and routes all traffic
on the Postgresql endpoint to that node. If the leader node goes down,
Patroni holds an election to chose a new leader and updates the endpoint
to route traffic accordingly. All communication between nodes is done by
a Patroni created endpoint, seperate from the externally facing Postgres
endpoint.

- Picking up patchset: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/591663

Co-authored-by: Tony Sorrentino <as1413@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Randeep Jalli <rj2083@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>
Change-Id: I721b745017dc1ea7ae05dfd9f8d5dd08d0965985
'}, {'created': '2019-04-29 18:42:39.000000000', 'message': 'Patroni inclusion work for HA Postgres

'}, {'created': '2019-05-06 22:45:53.000000000', 'message': 'Patroni inclusion work for HA Postgres

This patchset aims to add HA Clustering support for Postgres. HA Clustering
provides automatic failover in the event of the database going down in addition
to keeping replicas of the database for rebuilding in the event of a node
going down. To achieve this clustering we use
[Patroni](https://github.com/zalando/patroni) which offers HA clustering
support for Postgres.

Patroni is a daemon that runs in the background and keeps track of which
node in your cluster is currently the leader node and routes all traffic
on the Postgresql endpoint to that node. If the leader node goes down,
Patroni holds an election to chose a new leader and updates the endpoint
to route traffic accordingly. All communication between nodes is done by
a Patroni created endpoint, seperate from the externally facing Postgres
endpoint.

- Picking up patchset: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/591663

Co-authored-by: Tony Sorrentino <as1413@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Randeep Jalli <rj2083@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>
Change-Id: I721b745017dc1ea7ae05dfd9f8d5dd08d0965985

'}, {'created': '2019-05-09 13:30:29.000000000', 'message': 'Patroni inclusion work for HA Postgres

This patchset aims to add HA Clustering support for Postgres. HA Clustering
provides automatic failover in the event of the database going down in addition
to keeping replicas of the database for rebuilding in the event of a node
going down. To achieve this clustering we use
[Patroni](https://github.com/zalando/patroni) which offers HA clustering
support for Postgres.

Patroni is a daemon that runs in the background and keeps track of which
node in your cluster is currently the leader node and routes all traffic
on the Postgresql endpoint to that node. If the leader node goes down,
Patroni holds an election to chose a new leader and updates the endpoint
to route traffic accordingly. All communication between nodes is done by
a Patroni created endpoint, seperate from the externally facing Postgres
endpoint.

- Picking up patchset: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/591663

Co-authored-by: Tony Sorrentino <as1413@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Randeep Jalli <rj2083@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>
Change-Id: I721b745017dc1ea7ae05dfd9f8d5dd08d0965985

'}, {'created': '2019-05-13 00:48:10.000000000', 'message': 'Patroni inclusion work for HA Postgres

This patchset aims to add HA Clustering support for Postgres. HA Clustering
provides automatic failover in the event of the database going down in addition
to keeping replicas of the database for rebuilding in the event of a node
going down. To achieve this clustering we use
[Patroni](https://github.com/zalando/patroni) which offers HA clustering
support for Postgres.

Patroni is a daemon that runs in the background and keeps track of which
node in your cluster is currently the leader node and routes all traffic
on the Postgresql endpoint to that node. If the leader node goes down,
Patroni holds an election to chose a new leader and updates the endpoint
to route traffic accordingly. All communication between nodes is done by
a Patroni created endpoint, seperate from the externally facing Postgres
endpoint.

Note that, although the postgresql helm chart can be upgraded from
non-patroni to patroni clustering, the previous `postgresql`
endpoints object (which is not directly managed by helm) must be
deleted via an out-of-band mechanism so that it may be replaced by the
patroni-managed endpoints.  If Postgres itself is leveraged for the
deployment process, this must be done with careful timing.  Note that
the old endpoints had a port named "db", and the new endpoints has
a port named "postgresql".

- Picking up patchset: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/591663

Co-authored-by: Tony Sorrentino <as1413@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Randeep Jalli <rj2083@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>
Co-authored-by: Matt McEuen <mm9745@att.com>

Change-Id: I721b745017dc1ea7ae05dfd9f8d5dd08d0965985

'}, {'created': '2019-05-16 13:36:47.000000000', 'message': 'Patroni inclusion work for HA Postgres

This patchset aims to add HA Clustering support for Postgres. HA Clustering
provides automatic failover in the event of the database going down in addition
to keeping replicas of the database for rebuilding in the event of a node
going down. To achieve this clustering we use
[Patroni](https://github.com/zalando/patroni) which offers HA clustering
support for Postgres.

Patroni is a daemon that runs in the background and keeps track of which
node in your cluster is currently the leader node and routes all traffic
on the Postgresql endpoint to that node. If the leader node goes down,
Patroni holds an election to chose a new leader and updates the endpoint
to route traffic accordingly. All communication between nodes is done by
a Patroni created endpoint, seperate from the externally facing Postgres
endpoint.

Note that, although the postgresql helm chart can be upgraded from
non-patroni to patroni clustering, the previous `postgresql`
endpoints object (which is not directly managed by helm) must be
deleted via an out-of-band mechanism so that it may be replaced by the
patroni-managed endpoints.  If Postgres itself is leveraged for the
deployment process, this must be done with careful timing.  Note that
the old endpoints had a port named "db", and the new endpoints has
a port named "postgresql".

- Picking up patchset: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/591663

Co-authored-by: Tony Sorrentino <as1413@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Randeep Jalli <rj2083@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>
Co-authored-by: Matt McEuen <mm9745@att.com>

Change-Id: I721b745017dc1ea7ae05dfd9f8d5dd08d0965985

commit_message:
Patroni inclusion work for HA Postgres

This patchset aims to add HA Clustering support for Postgres. HA Clustering
provides automatic failover in the event of the database going down in addition
to keeping replicas of the database for rebuilding in the event of a node
going down. To achieve this clustering we use
[Patroni](https://github.com/zalando/patroni) which offers HA clustering
support for Postgres.

Patroni is a daemon that runs in the background and keeps track of which
node in your cluster is currently the leader node and routes all traffic
on the Postgresql endpoint to that node. If the leader node goes down,
Patroni holds an election to chose a new leader and updates the endpoint
to route traffic accordingly. All communication between nodes is done by
a Patroni created endpoint, seperate from the externally facing Postgres
endpoint.

Note that, although the postgresql helm chart can be upgraded from
non-patroni to patroni clustering, the previous `postgresql`
endpoints object (which is not directly managed by helm) must be
deleted via an out-of-band mechanism so that it may be replaced by the
patroni-managed endpoints.  If Postgres itself is leveraged for the
deployment process, this must be done with careful timing.  Note that
the old endpoints had a port named "db", and the new endpoints has
a port named "postgresql".

- Picking up patchset: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/591663

Co-authored-by: Tony Sorrentino <as1413@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Randeep Jalli <rj2083@att.com>
Co-authored-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>
Co-authored-by: Matt McEuen <mm9745@att.com>

Change-Id: I721b745017dc1ea7ae05dfd9f8d5dd08d0965985

- Update location of clones repos

commit_message:
Re-add amphora flavor management settings

The octavia amphora flavor config was inadvertantly removed during the
flattening stage. This adds it back.

Change-Id: Ic928d3562583291f4d640d6ccdc3d9d9b22a7866

[{'created': '2019-05-10 04:50:39.000000000', 'message': "[redhat] Update variables to be version agnostic

The RedHat-based operating systems such as CentOS have a pretty
stable list of packages, therefore, we don't need to pin it by
version and we can instead move to a much more generic redhat.yml
which will support a bigger range of systems.

Change-Id: I7058bf708648753981bcd43d7a0ad80067a49b0b
"}, {'created': '2019-05-28 11:02:15.000000000', 'message': "[redhat] Update variables to be version agnostic

The RedHat-based operating systems such as CentOS have a pretty
stable list of packages, therefore, we don't need to pin it by
version and we can instead move to a much more generic redhat.yml
which will support a bigger range of systems.

Change-Id: I7058bf708648753981bcd43d7a0ad80067a49b0b
"}]
commit_message:
[redhat] Update variables to be version agnostic

The RedHat-based operating systems such as CentOS have a pretty
stable list of packages, therefore, we don't need to pin it by
version and we can instead move to a much more generic redhat.yml
which will support a bigger range of systems.

Change-Id: I7058bf708648753981bcd43d7a0ad80067a49b0b

DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception is caused by using sf_allow_template_caching in an HA A/A environment.  Cinder driver has the same ability to cache image volumes and manage them through cinder.conf.   sf_allow_template_caching  will be removed in some future release.   Any one  experiencing this error should switch to cinder's version of image-caching"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-02 13:54:35.000000000', 'message': 'NetApp SolidFire: handle DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception

    When the cinder SolidFire driver is used in a high availability
    environment that is set to active/active with multiple
    c-volume-solidfire services running, multiple SolidFire template image
    volumes may be created for the same nova-image-uuid.

    When this is happens the DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception is thrown,
    the cinder-scheduler will retry the operation unsuccessfully. The work
    around is to use the SolidFire interface/api and remove the duplicate
    sf-template-cache-volume.

    This fixes the DuplicateSfVolumesName by catching the exception and
    deleting the all older sf-template-cache-volumes leaving the newest.

    "lock_image_operation_id" and "lock_source_operation_id" are now set
     to be external locks as a default this should help the unsupported
     use in High Availability(HA) Active/Active (AA) configurations

Change-Id: Ie3a6552b7d3b4c2333c913f645a877c4a24f554d
Closes-Bug:1813210
'}]
commit_message:
NetApp SolidFire: handle DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception

    When the cinder SolidFire driver is used in a high availability
    environment that is set to active/active with multiple
    c-volume-solidfire services running, multiple SolidFire template image
    volumes may be created for the same nova-image-uuid.

    When this is happens the DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception is thrown,
    the cinder-scheduler will retry the operation unsuccessfully. The work
    around is to use the SolidFire interface/api and remove the duplicate
    sf-template-cache-volume.

    This fixes the DuplicateSfVolumesName by catching the exception and
    deleting the all older sf-template-cache-volumes leaving the newest.

    "lock_image_operation_id" and "lock_source_operation_id" are now set
     to be external locks as a default this should help the unsupported
     use in High Availability(HA) Active/Active (AA) configurations

Change-Id: Ie3a6552b7d3b4c2333c913f645a877c4a24f554d
Closes-Bug:1813210

subject: NetApp SolidFire: handle DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception

- dsvm-tempest-infinibox-iscsi http://openstack-ci-logs.aws.infinidat.com/28/648228/1/check/dsvm-tempest-infinibox-iscsi/1f4ede7 : SUCCESS in 1h 15m 42s'}, {'account_id': 10058, 'date': '2019-04-04 13:52:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(15 comments)

Hi Jay, 
Thanks for working on this. As I see now, there's 3 cases we need to handle here:
 1 - Image is being created and does not have a duplicate;
 2 - Image is being created and have a duplicate on the storage;
 3 - Cluster has 2 duplicates already present from previous operations;

So, for case 1 and 2, first thing we need to do is to change the 
locked_image_id_operation() -> external=True. The user will need to use a
distributed lock in order get make it work.
Without this, 2 nodes can start the operation at the same time, get the volume
list from the cluster (which would not have the volume image), and create the
duplicate image.

Then, considering that we have the lock working, in case 1 we go ahead and
create the image, in case 2 we just return and we will never have a duplicate.

Case 3 might happen when you have a legacy cluster and is updated to the
current version. For this case, whenever you get a found_count > 1 just delete
older one."}, {'account_id': 28710, 'date': '2019-04-25 02:34:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 24921, 'date': '2019-04-25 02:35:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-27 20:08:29.000000000', 'message': 'SF handle DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception

When the cinder solidfire driver is used in a high availability
environment that is set to active/active with multiple
c-volume-solidfires services running, multiple solidfire template image
volumes may be created for the same image.  This happens on a
openstack/cinder create volume from image command.

When this is discovered the DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception is thrown,
the cinder-scheduler will retry the operation unsuccessfully. The work
around is to use the solidfire interface/api and remove the duplicate
template.

On the unpatched queens release this may cause volumes in the same
account to be deleted(that has a separate fix that is in the field)

This fixes the DuplicateSfVolumesName by catching the exception and
deleting the newer template duplicate images, keep the oldest one.

Change-Id: I6204aabcafa3b7b77167238d4344355370dc4567
Closes-Bug:1813210
'}, {'created': '2019-04-25 02:34:32.000000000', 'message': 'NetApp SolidFire: handle DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception

When the cinder SolidFire driver is used in a high availability
environment that is set to active/active with multiple
c-volume-solidfire services running, multiple SolidFire template image
volumes may be created for the same nova-image-uuid.

When this is happens the DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception is thrown,
the cinder-scheduler will retry the operation unsuccessfully. The work
around is to use the SolidFire interface/api and remove the duplicate
sf-template-cache-volume.

This fixes the DuplicateSfVolumesName by catching the exception and
deleting the all older sf-template-cache-volumes leaving the newest.

Change-Id: I6204aabcafa3b7b77167238d4344355370dc4567
Closes-Bug:1813210
'}, {'created': '2019-04-25 13:38:32.000000000', 'message': 'NetApp SolidFire: handle DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception

When the cinder SolidFire driver is used in a high availability
environment that is set to active/active with multiple
c-volume-solidfire services running, multiple SolidFire template image
volumes may be created for the same nova-image-uuid.

When this is happens the DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception is thrown,
the cinder-scheduler will retry the operation unsuccessfully. The work
around is to use the SolidFire interface/api and remove the duplicate
sf-template-cache-volume.

This fixes the DuplicateSfVolumesName by catching the exception and
deleting the all older sf-template-cache-volumes leaving the newest.

Change-Id: I6204aabcafa3b7b77167238d4344355370dc4567
Closes-Bug:1813210
'}]
commit_message:
NetApp SolidFire: handle DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception

When the cinder SolidFire driver is used in a high availability
environment that is set to active/active with multiple
c-volume-solidfire services running, multiple SolidFire template image
volumes may be created for the same nova-image-uuid.

When this is happens the DuplicateSfVolumeNames exception is thrown,
the cinder-scheduler will retry the operation unsuccessfully. The work
around is to use the SolidFire interface/api and remove the duplicate
sf-template-cache-volume.

This fixes the DuplicateSfVolumesName by catching the exception and
deleting the all older sf-template-cache-volumes leaving the newest.

Change-Id: I6204aabcafa3b7b77167238d4344355370dc4567
Closes-Bug:1813210

commit_message:
Blacklist bandit 1.6.0 & cap sphinx for 2.7

The latest version of bandit has broken directory
exclusion, so multiple test files are getting
flagged. This change blocks version 1.6.0 while
this issue is fixed for 1.6.1.

This change also caps sphinx at <2.0.0 for python version 2.7.

Change-Id: Id4db764200be068df0dbe96306c2d53f79b49af7

commit_message:
Switch rax.dfw mirror to opendev.org

We now have an opendev.org mirror in rax.dfw region (see
I26b9ed1e21e2111f48bc7ecc384880c274eed213 and related changes).

Switch this in for initial testing.  As mentioned, this can grow as we
bring new mirrors online, but will eventually be removed once all
opendev.org mirrors are active.

Change-Id: I631e3e3592a9be5c7da642cf34eec6d9758bf161

commit_message:
db_setup: refactor database setup to a common file

This patch refactors the database creation to db_setup.yml which
will eventually be managed by openstack-ansible-tests.

This also re-orders the mq_setup to be done earlier so these system
level dependencies are ready before service activation.

Change-Id: I53de65d666a014b23a69b246591fc0445f3ad64d

commit_message:
Install fluentd gem on debian/ubuntu for non x86_64

The package used to install fluentd on debian/ubuntu is not
available for architectures other than x86_64. For those cases
install fluentd as a gem until the package 'td-agent' is available
for more architectures.

Change-Id: Ic1b25b37d06b429a112f1418a79d385d505bb1e9

commit_message:
Pin ARA to <1.0.0 and use stable setup interface to find callback plugin

ARA 1.0 will be released in the near future and isn't backwards
compatible.
Pin it so it doesn't break things unexpectedly.

ARA ships simple setup modules to help figure out the paths
to where things are located.
These are backwards compatible from ARA 1.0 to 0.x.

Change-Id: Ie4dbaf54b2fee1ab9a6d5593fe34267dcd4e91db
(cherry picked from commit 86e9b0831c89352d062bb828e28af33240b94f89)

commit_message:
Try a timesync as part of first boot

We're running into issues where if someone creates a firstboot script
that touches a file that will eventually be mounted into a container, it
can fail if the time of the file ends up being in the future due to a
later timesync. Let's try a basic timesync bootstrap as part of
cloud-init to address the case of configuration changes occuring prior
to the host_prep_tasks where we traditionally configure chrony/ntp

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/659398
Change-Id: I294eba826b98c5793336815282f766e3d2e60a51
Related-Bug: #1776869
(cherry picked from commit eafe3908535ec766866efb74110e057ea2509c45)

commit_message:
Try a timesync as part of first boot

We're running into issues where if someone creates a firstboot script
that touches a file that will eventually be mounted into a container, it
can fail if the time of the file ends up being in the future due to a
later timesync. Let's try a basic timesync bootstrap as part of
cloud-init to address the case of configuration changes occuring prior
to the host_prep_tasks where we traditionally configure chrony/ntp

NOTE: For Rocky, we use ntp instead of chrony.

Change-Id: I294eba826b98c5793336815282f766e3d2e60a51
Related-Bug: #1776869
(cherry picked from commit eafe3908535ec766866efb74110e057ea2509c45)

commit_message:
Add APIMicroversionFixture to library interface

APIMicroversionFixture is used to set the microversion on
service clients which will take care of reseting the microversion.

This interface has been added to set the microversion on all supported
service clients which use microverison. User can set multiple
service microversion all together.

Using the new interface in compute tests to make sure it is all
working in serial and parallel testing.

Change-Id: I6ed41b02041d38c2c92c58b0d3dd6613d03da3f7

commit_message:
Only add internal_api_virtual_ip if InternalApi in network_data

Add's a conditional to only include internal_api_virtual_ip if
InternalApi network is defined in custom networks.

According to code comment internal_api_virtual_ip is only used
by Contrail.

Conflicts:
    puppet/all-nodes-config.j2.yaml

Change-Id: Ifd8f59bd03c9bab1283e580a64957f201eb8f335
Closes-Bug: #1772124
(cherry picked from commit 868c7685f19acdfba4aaa29ae1e12522d904f95f)

pivoted from using a trait to using a resource class.  However one

commit_message:
Update SEV work item to new approach based on MEM_ENCRYPTION_CONTEXT

Between the Stein and Train versions of the AMD SEV spec, the design
pivoted from using a trait to using a resource class.  However one
work item was missed from the switch, so fix it.

The significant point here is that the original RequestSpec doesn't
necessarily contain the SEV trait, e.g. if the user or operator has no
preference whether to boot the VM using SEV or some competing
technology.  In this case the placement service will ensure that
launch happens on a host which is capable of *some* kind of memory
encryption, and then later at spawn-time the virt driver can figure
out which technology can be used to deliver it.  This work item covers
the latter stage.

Change-Id: I615aa63a4bfe367dc93bf6805ea0038591eebd8b
blueprint: amd-sev-libvirt-support

This adds required changes to the Fluentd chart to allow for
deploying Fluentd as either a deployment or a daemonset. This

commit_message:
Fluentd: Support Daemonset deployment

This adds required changes to the Fluentd chart to allow for
deploying Fluentd as either a deployment or a daemonset. This
follows the pattern laid out by the ingress chart. This also
updates the single and multinode jobs to deploy fluentd as both
a daemonset and a deployment for validation

Change-Id: I84353a2daa2ce56ff59882a8d33203286ed27e06
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

recheck'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-05-21 16:40:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I wonder how this will pass if it's run against a stable branch?"}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-05-21 17:12:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I wonder how this will pass if it's run against a stable branch?

That is interesting question :)
At least it proves that fix works fine.

I see 3 possible solutions here:
 - use API extension to make this change discoverable (I don't think it is good idea),
 - wait with this patch until patch in neutron will be merged and back ported up to Queens,
 - add this test to blacklist in stable branches job for now - and remove it when patch in neutron will be backported to stable branch.

IMHO 3rd solution is the best but what do You think?"}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-05-21 18:06:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> - add this test to blacklist in stable branches job for now - and remove it when patch in neutron will be backported to stable branch.

How do we do this, isn't it a chicken/egg problem?  We can't blacklist the test until it's added and we can't add it until it's blacklisted :)
Or do you just mark it unstable here?

And it raises a question - won't we still possibly break downstream consumers if they don't have the neutron change?  Just thinking out loud."}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-05-21 20:25:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-05-21 20:27:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > - add this test to blacklist in stable branches job for now - and
 > remove it when patch in neutron will be backported to stable
 > branch.
 > 
 > How do we do this, isn't it a chicken/egg problem?  We can't
 > blacklist the test until it's added and we can't add it until it's
 > blacklisted :)
 > Or do you just mark it unstable here?

I just added this test to be blacklisted in tempest regex in specific jobs. That should works IMO but lets see how it will be :)

 > 
 > And it raises a question - won't we still possibly break downstream
 > consumers if they don't have the neutron change?  Just thinking out
 > loud.

Yes, basically that can break some d/s product which is using neutron-tempest-plugin from master branch and will run it against any stable release up to Queens.
But I really don't know what we can do we it except backport this fix ASAP to stable branches. Do You have any idea what we can do with this?"}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-05-22 03:11:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Let's see what Nate thinks, I guess I'm Ok with this even though it's a little bit of a hack using the blacklist."}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-05-22 19:29:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Do we have any stadium projects that depend on neutron, that pull neutron from pip instead of pulling from master?  I'm thinking of the issues we have had with neutron-lib and needing to wait for a published release for fixes, and I wonder since nearly all stadium projects consume neutron still if we might get ourselves in the same situation where a stadium project is broken until we get a new release of neutron.  So do we have any stadium projects that have jobs where tox_install_siblings is false?  

If that is the case, I don't see a way around putting a skip in for the test at least until we hit T-1."}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-05-22 19:37:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Other possible solution for that issue is to propose backport of neutron patch now and make this one depend on all backport patches too. Then it should run fine for all stable releases here.
Would it be better?"}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2019-05-23 14:01:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-05-24 12:56:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Add API test case to check if SG displays all rules

This patch adds new API test which checks if owner of security group
can see rules which belongs to his security group even if rule was
created and belongs to other user (admin).

Patch for master branch:
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/660174

Backport to stable/Stein:
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/661281

Backport to stable/Rocky:
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/661283

Backport to stable/Queens:
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/661284

Change-Id: I728cd8252d27e27e91bd95e4734d9db470dee35a
Related-Bug: #1824248

commit_message:
Show all SG rules belong to SG in group's details

If security group contains rule(s) which were created by different
user (admin), owner of this security group should see such rules
even if those rules don't belong to him.

This patch changes to use admin_context to get security group rules
in get_security_group() method to achieve that.

Test to cover such case is added in neutron-tempest-plugin repo.

Conflicts:
    neutron/db/securitygroups_db.py

Change-Id: I890c81bb6eabc5caa620ed4fcc4dc88ebfa6e1b0
Closes-Bug: #1824248
(cherry picked from commit 1920a37a94b7a9589dcf83f6ff0765068560dbf8)
(cherry picked from commit 252d80058cacc797fbfb970ad42031efe301b0e2)
